Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Elucidating the Molecular Architecture and Dynamics of Phenylalanine Biosynthesis in Plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The amino acid phenylalanine is the precursor for the synthesis of >8000 phenolic compounds in plants, which have profound impacts on plant growth, development, reproduction and defense. Phenylalanine serves as a precursor for numerous plant natural products that are widely used in medicine and as food supplements. This project will characterize a new pathway for phenylalanie synthesis in the plant cytostol determine the contribution of this pathway to the total phenylalanine production. The results will significantly contribute to the fundamental knowledge of a major plant metabolic network and provide a better understanding of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis. Such information will allow rational metabolic engineering of phenylalanine levels for production of important phenylalanine-derived compounds to improve agronomic traits, biofuel production, palatability of produce, and commercial value of ornamentals. The plannned research will provide multidisciplinary training to undergraduate and graduate students. The educational program will also introduce students from a local middle school to STEM-based research through direct classroom interactions and facilitating laboratory exercises where students generate and test hypotheses.

It has long been accepted that aromatic amino acid biosynthesis occurs exclusively in plastids where it is subject to complex feedback regulation both at the entry point into the network and at the committed steps towards individual amino acids. The recent finding that phenylalanine is also formed in the cytosol raises new questions about how plants regulate carbon flux distribution between the parallel pathways. This project will employ an integrative strategy comprised of genetics, molecular biology, metabolic profiling, protein and membrane biochemistry, stable-isotope labeling, and metabolic flux analysis to determine if (i) plants contain a complete cytosolic pathway, (ii) this route is subject to less stringent feedback regulation, and (iii) the flux through this pathway increases when the demand for phenylalanine production and consumption increases. Petunia flowers, which are amenable to genetic alterations without deleterious effects to plant vitality, and are rich in phenylalanine and phenylalanine-derived volatiles, will be used as a model system. Specifically, this project will uncover the pathway structure and the molecular players of the cytosolic phenylalanine biosynthesis. Moreover, the project will reveal the capacity and relative contribution of the cytosolic route to overall production of phenylalanine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The amino acid phenylalanine is the precursor for the synthesis of >8000 phenolic compounds in plants, which have profound impacts on plant growth, development, reproduction and defense. Phenylalanine serves as a precursor for numerous plant natural products that are widely used in medicine and as food supplements. This project aimed at characterizing a new pathway for phenylalanine synthesis in the plant cytosol and determine the contribution of this pathway to the total phenylalanine production. This knowledge would allow rational metabolic engineering of phenylalanine levels for production of important phenylalanine-derived compounds to improve agronomic traits, biofuel production, palatability of produce, and commercial value of ornamentals.

It has long been accepted that aromatic amino acid biosynthesis occurs exclusively in chloroplasts and similar organelles (i.e. plastids), where it is subject to complex feedback regulation both at the entry point into the network and at the committed steps towards individual amino acids. The finding that phenylalanine is also formed in the cytosol raised new questions about how plants regulate carbon flux distribution between the parallel pathways of the cytosol and plastids. Petunia flowers, which are amenable to genetic alterations without deleterious effects to plant vitality, and are rich in phenylalanine and phenylalanine-derived volatiles, were used as a model system.

Our collaborator at Purdue University employed an integrative strategy comprised of genetics, molecular biology, metabolic profiling, protein and membrane biochemistry, stable-isotope labeling, and metabolic flux analysis to characterize the cytosolic pathway. The precursor of phenylalanine is synthesized by the plastidial shikimate pathway, and it is yet unknown which intermediary, chorismate or shikimate, is the exported from the plastid to feed the cytosolic phenylalanine biosynthesis pathway. First using bioinformatics, then a yeast-based screening, we searched for transporters of shikimate and chorismate. Despite numerous attempts, we could not isolate a gene that would restore yeast growth on selective medium, putatively encoding a chorismate transporter. On the other hand, we successfully isolated a shikimate transporter. Similarity searches in Petunia and Arabidopsis and functional characterization in yeast led to the isolation of three other shikimate-specific transporters.

The results will significantly contribute to the fundamental knowledge of a major plant metabolic network and provide a better understanding of aromatic amino acid biosynthesis. Specifically, this project uncovered the pathway structure and the molecular players of the cytosolic phenylalanine biosynthesis. Moreover, the project laid ground work for determining the capacity and relative contribution of the cytosolic route to overall production of phenylalanine.

We disseminated our results in scientific publications and at local and international conferences. This research provided multidisciplinary training to undergraduate and graduate students. The educational program also introduced students from a local high school to STEM-based research through direct classroom interactions and facilitating laboratory exercises where students generated and tested hypotheses. The students performed experiments with mutant plants altered in amino acid transport. The student were asked to choose conditions to grow the plants in the classroom, gathered data on plant fitness, appearance, size, etc? and analyzed the data to draw conclusion on the effect of the mutations on plant development. The faculty met several times during a semester with the high school students to assess progress and help with the analyses.
